description: Borrowed from Ancient Greek ὀνοματοποιία (onomatopoiía, “the coining of a word in imitation of a sound”), from ὀνοματοποιέω (onomatopoiéō, “to coin names”), from ὄνομα (ónoma, “name”) + ποιέω (poiéō, “to make, to do, to produce”).

nouns.description: onomatopoeia (countable and uncountable, plural onomatopoeias or onomatopoeiae)

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The property of a word of sounding like what it represents.

definitionGroups.group: (countable) A word that sounds like what it represents, such as "gurgle," "stutter," or "hiss".

entries.meaning: (countable) A word that appropriates a sound for another sensation or a perceived nature, such as "thud", "beep", or "meow"; an ideophone, phenomime.
(uncountable, rhetoric) The use of language whose sound imitates that which it names.
